thread.title: If Tyrone Mings didn't mean to trample on Zlatan Ibrahimovic - why wouldn't he check he was OK?
thread.title_full: If Tyrone Mings didn't mean to trample on Zlatan Ibrahimovic - why wouldn't he check he was OK?

author: Robbie Savage
title: If Tyrone Mings didn't mean to trample on Zlatan Ibrahimovic - why wouldn't he check he was OK?
text:
Sav has his say on the Mings and Ibrahimovic incident Share Get Manchester United FC   Thank you for subscribing!   
Back in 2004, I was among the first players handed a retrospective ban in English football based on a so-called trial by TV evidence. 
I served a three-match suspension for elbowing Chelsea's Mateja Kezman – although I will swear to my dying day that it wasn't intentional and I would happily take a lie detector test to prove it. 
But I don't completely buy Tyrone Mings' protest that he did not mean to trample on Zlatan Ibrahimovic's head at Old Trafford last weekend, which earned him a retrospective five-match ban. 
And the disciplinary tribunal's decision that it was deliberate has opened a massive can of worms because they have decreed that Mings' action was laced with intent. Mings caught in the act (Photo: Sky Sports) Mings and Ibrahimovic had a game-long battle (Photo: PA) Read More Tyrone Mings hits out at the FA for his five-game ban for stamping on Zlatan 
The Bournemouth defender has issued a statement, insisting it was an “accidental collision” and that stepping on a fellow professional's head is “not part of my game.” 
OK, I accept that Mings did not set out to stamp on Ibrahimovic – there was no acceleration of his foot, in a downward motion, that made it look like premeditated violence. 
But in my experience, if your foot is in danger of connecting with an opponent's head, you find a way to pull out of the challenge at all costs. 
You collapse your leg, you change direction, you tilt your ankle through 45 degrees, you do anything and everything possible to avoid contact between boot and head – because that is potentially one of the most damaging forms of collision in the game. Mings and Ibrahimovic clash (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) Mings will miss the next five games through suspension (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) 
That applies whether you are kicking a ball around the garden with your kids, playing Sunday parks football or you're a Premier League player earning £250,000-a-week. 
And if you do tread on somebody's head, you can't ignore it. Surely it is human nature to stop and wonder if you have hurt them? 
If Zlatan gets a three-match ban for elbowing Mings at the corner which followed shortly after – which did look like an intentional act – I would agree with Bournemouth manager Eddie Howe that five games in the sin bin for Mings is harsh. 
We are setting out down a very dangerous road in football if panels can make assumptions of intent when, in reality, the only person on the planet who truly knows whether Mings meant to step on Zlatan's head is Mings himself. 
As much as we laughed off Ibrahimovic's claim that Mings jumped into his elbow, how can we actually prove otherwise? Ibrahimovic gets his revenge - which earned him a three game ban (Photo: REUTERS) Read More Video-replay experiment can "remove many scars from referees' backs" as it exposes cheats, thugs — and howlers 
But on the other hand, if I was lying on the floor and a 6ft 5in defender planted his boot on my head, I would probably go looking for him and give him a whack. 
I would call Mings' actions trampling without due care for the well-being of a fellow professional. If five games was harsh, he shouldn't be let off scot-free, either. 
What I'm not having is any fluff that he's “not that type of player.” That old chestnut is one of the biggest cop-outs in football. 
Bournemouth said in a statement Mings had only been booked 13 times in 75 appearances, and not at all since April 2015, before his close encounter with Zlatan. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
